surfaceLines: Before my bed, the moonlight lies.
Perhaps it is frost upon the ground.
I raise my head to watch the moon.
I bow my head and think of home.

choices.stakes: Opens the visual tableau and meter for a balanced jueju-style quatrain; sets register (plain vs. elevated) and governs parallelism with line 2.

alternatives.text: Before my bed, the moonlight lies.
alternatives.note: Smooth cadence that mirrors the parallel phrasing of the Chinese; idiomatic ‘lies’ supplies an English verb while preserving stillness.
Closer to the source word order; paratactic feel foregrounds Classical Chinese concision.

alternatives.text: By my bed the bright moonlight falls,
alternatives.note: Adds an explicit verb and epithets; slightly more descriptive than the source.

choices.stakes: Handles the ambiguity of ‘疑是’ (uncertainty) and the setting noun (‘ground’ vs. ‘floor’) which shifts scene from outdoors to domestic interior; couples antithetically with line 0.

alternatives.text: Perhaps it is frost upon the ground.
alternatives.note: ‘Perhaps’ renders 疑; ‘ground’ maintains outdoor ambiguity and pairs cleanly with moonlight.

alternatives.text: I think it’s frost upon the floor.
alternatives.note: Internalizes doubt (‘I think’) and moves the scene inside with ‘floor’.

alternatives.text: As if frost lay on the earth.
alternatives.note: Simulative ‘as if’ for 疑; ‘earth’ heightens register and generality.

choices.stakes: Must echo line 3 in gesture (raise/bow) to maintain structural parallelism typical of jueju couplets; verb choice sets overall register.

alternatives.text: I raise my head to watch the moon.
alternatives.note: Direct mapping of 举头/望; understated and parallel-ready.

alternatives.text: Lifting my gaze, I behold the moon.
alternatives.note: Elevated diction (‘behold’) increases ceremonial tone; slightly recasts syntax.

alternatives.text: I look up and see the bright moon.
alternatives.note: Everyday idiom; adds ‘bright’ explicitly to echo 明.

choices.stakes: Closes the emotional arc; must balance with line 2’s upward motion. Word choice for 故乡 (‘home’, ‘homeland’) sets affect (personal vs. formal).

alternatives.text: I bow my head and think of home.
alternatives.note: Direct translation of 低头思故乡—preserves physical act and plain affect.

alternatives.text: Head bent, I'm seized with homesickness.
alternatives.note: Intensifies emotion; trades quiet reflection for overt feeling.

alternatives.text: I lower my gaze, remembering my distant homeland.
alternatives.note: Adds ‘distant’ and selects ‘homeland’ for elevated register and scope.

alternatives.text: And drop my head, dreaming of home.
alternatives.note: Leans into reverie by rendering 思 as ‘dreaming’.

axes.label: Closer to Chinese ↔ More natural English
